[48]What about the a case? 
[49]Eight-two-one.

dialogues.Father:
[1]You are American. 
[2]You speak Italian? 
[3]Va bene! You stay at Pensione Arbruzzo. 
[4]On vacation? 
[5]Lavoro? Che genere de lavoro? 
[6]Va bene. Che genere de fotografia? 
[7]People? 
[8]Ah! Magazine! Which magazine? 
[9]Va bene. So you must share a glass of wine with me. Questa sera. This evening. 
[10]Certo. You want to know the truth about Abruzzo? A priest sees everything. 
[11]      
[12]Que siamo! The quality of the brandy is good, the liquor is smooth and the glass warmed by the sun. 
[13] 
[14]The French are... pezzi di merda. This is not an American discovery. Italians have known this for centuries. [In ITALIAN] When Rome called France the province of Gaul, they were just the same. Arrogant sensualists. Their cuisine is fussy and their wine effeminate. Only their brandy is worthy of any attention. 
[15] 
[16]You come to Italy to make a guide book and you don't care about history? 
[17]Of course. You are American. You think you can escape history. You live for the present. 
[18]        
[19]        
[20]All the sheep in my flock are dear to me, but some are dearer than most. Especially those that have strayed from the fold. 
[21]Fabio. He is a... [in ITALIAN] 'car doctor'. But I suspect his practice is not entirely sound. Ecco! 
[22]Fagiano. Pheasant. With sauce of orange juice, orange peel, chestnuts, garlic, Marsala wine and... Come si dici in Inglese? Brodo di Pollo. Chicken broth. 
[23]Also: salsify in garlic butter. Mange-tout. Fried wild mushrooms with truffle. 
[24]The Holy Father eats better than this. 
[25]Have you ever wanted to be anything other than a... come se dice in Inglese...? 
[26]Photographer. 
[27]I'm sure you have other talents. You have the hands of a craftsman, not an artist. You are good with machines. Yet you told me just the opposite when we first met. 
[28]Journalism cannot make you a rich man. 
[29]Perhaps you are rich already? 
[30] 
[31] 
[32]"The grave soul keeps its own secrets, and takes its own punishment in silence." 
[33]I've been looking for you. 
[34]A man was here asking questions about you. 
[35]He came to the church this afternoon. 
[36]To know where you live. He said he was a friend from Switzerland. 
[37]Of course I do not tell him. How do I know him? He is maybe the police. Certainly he is no friend. A friend would know your pensione. Besides... 
[38]Friends do not carry guns. 
[39]If you live in Italy, and you are a man of the cloth, you meet many people. Besides, I lived once in Naples. If you live in Naples you know the difference between a fat wallet and a... custodia per armi di spalla. How you say in English? 
[40]Si. 
[41]I am a priest. 
[42]Signor Clarke? 
[43]I make a mistake. He did not say he was from La Svizzera: Switzerland. He said- forgive me the names in Italian are so similar- La Svezia: Sweden. 
[44]Buon giorno! 
[45]I walk here to meditate. Once a week, Wednesday, the farthest one can travel in the week from the Sabbath. The trees are like the Stations of the Cross: by certain trees I thank God for certain favours he has granted me, or certain gifts he has made to me and all men. For example, here by this pine, I thank him for the many friendships I have and ask him to look after those of my friends who are troubled. 
[46]Some walk here in the cool of evening. Others come at night. 
[47]I wonder how many bastards have been made here? 
[48]Perhaps you'll stay and settle here yourself? 
[49]You told me as much when we first met. Besides, those who seek for peace seldom find it. They're always moving on, looking elsewhere. [A BEAT] And they are usually sinners. 
[50]Some are greater sinners than others. And those who seek peace have much sinning in their history. 
[51]Until now. 
[52]Forgive me. This is the priest in me speaking. And the friend. But you have done much sinning, Signor Clarke. You still do. 
[53]I do not refer to the sins of carnality. But to the deadly sins... 
[54]We are not discussing theology, my friend, but you. You like this town, this valley. 
[55]You should like to remain here and find your peace at last. Yet you cannot. There is something you cannot ignore. Some force. Some enemy. 
[56]You want to speak but you dare not. You know no one sufficiently well to share your history with them. You know I am trustworthy yet still you are cautious. 
[57]What job do you do, Signor? Are you on the run, as they say? 
[58]It's an expression, no? 
[59]Some men watch some of the shadows. You watch them all. 
[60]Do you wish to tell me? 
[61]For your own sake. Perhaps I can pray for you? 
[62]Counterfeit money? 
[63]You work in metal. You are given some steel by Fabio, the car doctor. 
[64]I know only what you do in the town. People talk to me. I am their priest and they trust me. 
[65]Of course. 
[66]Why do you ask me that? 
[67]I do not remember, Signor. It was twenty-five years ago. 
[68]In the end it is I who confesses to you. 
[69]Perhaps. For your own good. You cannot doubt the existence of Hell. You live in it. It is a place without love. As for me, I go about my daily duties because the town requires it of me. Some know what you know. Perhaps I have no right to wear these robes. But I do have a heart full of a father's love. Something close to His heart! And for that I am both grateful and happy. 
[70]What do you have, my friend? 
[71]Ciao Fabio, come stai? 
[72]Dear Father Benedetto. I promised myself that I would write to you- as your friend- to say goodbye... 
[73]Everything I've ever done... 
[74]I've done for a reason. 
[75] FATHER BENEDETTO stands stock still, facing JACK.  The SIRENS get louder.  
[76]I will them that the man who wrote this letter is my friend. 
[77]Jack.
